speaker: SPEAKER_1
text: Hi guys. So, today we are going to be talking about this topic regression analysis and in this topic I am going to teach you the conceptual knowledge of regression. It is used as a multivariate analysis technique to study the interdependence between many variables. You need a dependent variable and you need many independent variables. For the dependent variable one of the prerequisite is that the dependent variable should have been captured in a metric scale. Does anyone remember what is metric scale? So, Nishant do you want to take that question?
coach_notes: Encourage students to recall prior knowledge, fostering engagement.
iam_rationale: Asking a question to elicit information from students.

speaker: SPEAKER_0
text: Yes sir. So, I believe that a variable which is taken into a interval or a ratio scale is being taken into a metric scale. Wonderful. So, dependent variable if it is
coach_notes: Good response, but could be expanded with follow-up questions.
iam_rationale: Sharing personal understanding of metric scale.

speaker: SPEAKER_1
text: in metric scale and independent variables in any scale then we can run a regression. In regression there are two objectives one is to be able to predict your dependent variable and the other is to find out the drivers of the dependent variable. Now, in multiple linear regression we try to fit a line between the dependent variable and the independent variables.
coach_notes: Provide clear objectives to guide students' understanding.

speaker: SPEAKER_1
text: So, we capture the historic data and we plot that historic data and we try and fit a best line with that plot. Can you guess how can we fit a best line best fit line? If this is the kind of distribution that you can see on the white board what do you think can be the logic to fit a best fit line there? Yes Tejaswini do you want to take that question?
coach_notes: Encourage critical thinking by asking for solutions.
iam_rationale: Prompting students to explore how to fit a line.

speaker: SPEAKER_0
text: Yes sir. So, a line that passes through the maximum number of points can be the best fit
coach_notes: Encourage elaboration on this idea to deepen understanding.
iam_rationale: Sharing a suggestion for fitting a line.

speaker: SPEAKER_1
text: lines. Yes that is one logic and I like your answer except that Tejaswini if you look at the maximum number of points it may so happen that we may not get a unique solution. We may get two lines that passes through maximum number of points or maybe 3, 4, 5 in which case you know finding the best fit line would become a challenge. Class do you have any alternate solution to figuring out how given this distribution of points we can find a best fit line? Yes Nishant what are your thoughts on this?
coach_notes: Challenge students to think critically about their responses.
iam_rationale: Critiquing the previous suggestion and prompting for alternatives.

speaker: SPEAKER_0
text: So, sir I was thinking about a line that splits the point into equal counts on either half the same number of points on the left and the right side of the line.
coach_notes: Encourage further exploration of this idea.
iam_rationale: Sharing another suggestion for fitting a line.

speaker: SPEAKER_1
text: Yes. So, that is also possible we can have points which are equally distributed on either side of the line, but then again Nishant the same issue remains we may not get a unique solution. In fact, I can show you a line multiple lines that split the points into multiple into equal halves, but then they are not the best fit line clearly not the best fit line.
coach_notes: Encourage students to consider limitations of their ideas.
iam_rationale: Challenging the suggestion by discussing potential issues.

speaker: SPEAKER_1
text: So, in this case we will have to think deeper and find out what can be the solution and how can be a generic algorithm be found that can have that can give us the best fit line given this distribution of points. I would urge the class to think a little deeper and think about an alternate solution. Yes Tejaswini you are raising your hand.
coach_notes: Guide students to think critically and creatively.
iam_rationale: Encouraging deeper thought and exploration of solutions.

speaker: SPEAKER_0
text: Sir, how about a line that has minimum distance from all the points?
iam_rationale: Sharing a new idea for fitting a line.

speaker: SPEAKER_1
text: Yes, that can be a good way to figure out the best fit line, but by the way there is a technical word for this distance can you tell me Nishant what is this distance between any point and a corresponding point on the line. So, a distance between the actual y
coach_notes: Encourage students to recall specific terminology.

speaker: SPEAKER_0
text: value and the predicted y value. Sir, is it called the error or the residual?
coach_notes: Good recall; encourage application of this term in context.

speaker: SPEAKER_1
text: So, exactly that is called residual or the error. So, we are talking about a line that minimizes the error in y and I think that can be a good way to figure out the best fit line. So, we are talking about a line that has the least error from all the points and we find out the error for each point we square the error and we sum it up and the line that has these the least sum square of errors is called our best fit line and this algorithm is called the ordinary least square algorithm and it is used to fit the best fit line in case of a multiple linear regression. So, class now we understand an algorithm that can be used to fit a best fit line in case of multivariate scenario where we are trying to study the relationship of dependence using regression.
coach_notes: Summarize and clarify the concept effectively.
iam_rationale: Providing closure and integrating the discussion.
